In 48 hours I went from zero to a fully deployed, professional blog at datainsidedata.com.

ğŸ’¡ Why Jekyll Instead of Just HTML/CSS/JS?

When I started this, I asked myself: â€œWhy not just code a static site by hand?â€

Hereâ€™s why I chose Jekyll:

ğŸš€ 1. Built for Blogs

Jekyll was literally designed for blogs. It supports:

  • Markdown posts
  • Categories & tags out of the box
  • Auto-generated archive & pagination
  • Clean permalinks like /2025/07/12/why-jekyll.html

With pure HTML/CSS/JS, Iâ€™d have to hand-code all of that.

ğŸ’ 2. Minimalist and Professional

Jekyll doesnâ€™t need a heavy backend (no PHP, no databases).
Itâ€™s just static filesâ€”fast, secure, and deploys beautifully on GitHub Pages.

ğŸ§° 3. Gems and Themes = Less Reinventing the Wheel

  • The Minimal Mistakes theme gave me a professional design instantly.
  • Gems like jekyll-feed and jekyll-seo-tag handle RSS feeds & SEO for me.

Pure HTML/CSS/JS? Iâ€™d be reinventing:
âœ” Sitemap.xml
âœ” RSS feed
âœ” SEO metadata
âœ” Responsive layouts

ğŸ’¨ 4. One Command â†’ Whole Site Built

Jekyll lets me run:

bundle exec jekyll build

â€¦and it renders all posts, layouts, and assets into the _site folder, ready for deployment.

In a pure static setup, Iâ€™d manually copy/paste and keep track of every link. ğŸ˜¬

ğŸŒ Custom Domain with GitHub Pages + AWS Route 53

ğŸ—‚ Private + Public Repo Workflow

Since GitHub Pages doesnâ€™t serve from private repos unless you pay for Pro:

  1. Private repo: did-site-private (holds full Jekyll source)
  2. Public repo: did-site-public (hosts built site for Pages)

âš¡ Sneak Peek: Automating with GitHub Actions (No More _site Pushes!)

Hereâ€™s the workflow Iâ€™m planning:

ğŸ“‚ .github/workflows/deploy.yml

name: Build and Deploy Jekyll Site

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - main  # Watch for changes in private repo

jobs:
  build-deploy:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest

    steps:
    - name: Checkout private repo
      uses: actions/checkout@v3

    - name: Setup Ruby + Jekyll
      uses: ruby/setup-ruby@v1
      with:
        ruby-version: '3.1'

    - name: Install dependencies
      run: bundle install

    - name: Build site
      run: bundle exec jekyll build

    - name: Deploy to public repo
      uses: peaceiris/actions-gh-pages@v3
      with:
        github_token: $
        publish_dir: ./_site
        publish_branch: main
        destination_repo: dataeden/did-site-public
